input:
1. A 6-year-old boy was brought to the neurology clinic with delayed motor milestones and difficulty walking independently. His parents noticed frequent falls and progressive muscle weakness, primarily affecting his proximal limbs. On examination, he exhibited hypotonia, calf hypertrophy, and mild joint contractures. Cognitive development appeared normal, but he showed signs of mild intellectual delay. Creatine kinase levels were elevated, and electromyography suggested a myopathic pattern. Brain MRI revealed subtle structural abnormalities consistent with cortical dysplasia. Muscle biopsy demonstrated reduced glycosylation of alpha-dystroglycan, confirming a diagnosis of Muscular Dystrophy-Dystroglycanopathy, Type a, 5. Genetic testing identified a mutation in the FKRP gene, supporting the clinical and pathological findings.
What brings you in today?
output:
THINKING: I should honestly describe what’s been bothering me, but I might not be very clear because it’s confusing and I don’t really understand all this stuff. I’ll try to keep it simple but also mention what I feel the most.  
ANSWER: Well, I guess I just feel kinda tired more than usual and sometimes I get confused about my muscles, like they don’t always work right. My legs feel weird and I fall a lot, even when I don’t think I’m doing anything different.

input: 1. A 6-year-old boy was brought to the neurology clinic with delayed motor milestones and difficulty walking independently. His parents noticed frequent falls and progressive muscle weakness, primarily affecting his proximal limbs. On examination, he exhibited hypotonia, calf hypertrophy, and mild joint contractures. Cognitive development appeared normal, but he showed signs of mild intellectual delay. Creatine kinase levels were elevated, and electromyography suggested a myopathic pattern. Brain MRI revealed subtle structural abnormalities consistent with cortical dysplasia. Muscle biopsy demonstrated reduced glycosylation of alpha-dystroglycan, confirming a diagnosis of Muscular Dystrophy-Dystroglycanopathy, Type a, 5. Genetic testing identified a mutation in the FKRP gene, supporting the clinical and pathological findings.Can you tell me more about when these symptoms started, how they've changed over time, and if you've noticed anything that makes them better or worse?
output: Um, I think it started a little while ago, maybe when he was really little? Things haven't really gotten better, and sometimes he falls more or it's harder for him to move around, especially lately. I guess playing or being active makes it worse, but I don't really know why. It just feels kind of worse sometimes.

input: 1. A 6-year-old boy was brought to the neurology clinic with delayed motor milestones and difficulty walking independently. His parents noticed frequent falls and progressive muscle weakness, primarily affecting his proximal limbs. On examination, he exhibited hypotonia, calf hypertrophy, and mild joint contractures. Cognitive development appeared normal, but he showed signs of mild intellectual delay. Creatine kinase levels were elevated, and electromyography suggested a myopathic pattern. Brain MRI revealed subtle structural abnormalities consistent with cortical dysplasia. Muscle biopsy demonstrated reduced glycosylation of alpha-dystroglycan, confirming a diagnosis of Muscular Dystrophy-Dystroglycanopathy, Type a, 5. Genetic testing identified a mutation in the FKRP gene, supporting the clinical and pathological findings.Can you tell me more about how these symptoms have affected your daily life and if there are any specific activities or moments that make them worse or better?
output: Um, I don't really know how to say it, but I get tired a lot and sometimes I fall when I try to run or jump. There are times I feel a lot weaker and, like, stuff hurts more, especially if I try to do things fast. Maybe when I rest, I feel a little better, but I still feel weird sometimes.

input: 1. A 6-year-old boy was brought to the neurology clinic with delayed motor milestones and difficulty walking independently. His parents noticed frequent falls and progressive muscle weakness, primarily affecting his proximal limbs. On examination, he exhibited hypotonia, calf hypertrophy, and mild joint contractures. Cognitive development appeared normal, but he showed signs of mild intellectual delay. Creatine kinase levels were elevated, and electromyography suggested a myopathic pattern. Brain MRI revealed subtle structural abnormalities consistent with cortical dysplasia. Muscle biopsy demonstrated reduced glycosylation of alpha-dystroglycan, confirming a diagnosis of Muscular Dystrophy-Dystroglycanopathy, Type a, 5. Genetic testing identified a mutation in the FKRP gene, supporting the clinical and pathological findings.Can you tell me more about any other changes you've noticed in your body or mind, like differences in your thinking, mood, sensations, or any new symptoms that have developed alongside your current issues?
output: Um, sometimes I feel kinda tired more than before, even when I haven't done much. And I get these little numb feelings in my arms and legs sometimes, like pins and needles. It's kind of confusing, and I don’t really know if it’s connected or not.

input: 1. A 6-year-old boy was brought to the neurology clinic with delayed motor milestones and difficulty walking independently. output: No, I don’t think so. None of my family has seen the doctor for anything like this or have similar trouble walking or falling.

input: 1. A 6-year-old boy was brought to the neurology clinic with delayed motor milestones and difficulty walking independently. His parents noticed frequent falls and progressive muscle weakness, primarily affecting his proximal limbs. On examination, he exhibited hypotonia, calf hypertrophy, and mild joint contractures. Cognitive development appeared normal, but he showed signs of mild intellectual delay. Creatine kinase levels were elevated, and electromyography suggested a myopathic pattern. Brain MRI revealed subtle structural abnormalities consistent with cortical dysplasia. Muscle biopsy demonstrated reduced glycosylation of alpha-dystroglycan, confirming a diagnosis of Muscular Dystrophy-Dystroglycanopathy, Type a, 5. Genetic testing identified a mutation in the FKRP gene, supporting the clinical and pathological findings.Have you noticed if certain activities, times of day, or environmental factors make your symptoms better or worse?
output: Um, sometimes I get tired faster when I run a lot, and my legs feel kinda weak, like they don’t want to move as much as before. I don’t really know when it happens, but I just feel different sometimes.

output: I don't really know if my eyes are doing... something funny. Like, I don't see things right sometimes, and I get tired looking around, I think. My eyes might not move perfectly, but I don’t really feel pain or anything.

input: 1. A 6-year-old boy was brought to the neurology clinic with delayed motor milestones and difficulty walking independently. Muscle biopsy demonstrated reduced glycosylation of alpha-dystroglycan, confirming a diagnosis of Muscular Dystrophy-Dystroglycanopathy, Type a, 5. Genetic testing identified a mutation in the FKRP gene, supporting the clinical and pathological findings.Have you noticed any recent worsening or new symptoms in your vision, sensation, strength, or coordination that have developed since your last visit?
output: Um, he's been the same pretty much, but sometimes he just gets really tired when trying to play, and he falls more easily now. I don’t think anything's suddenly worse, but I’m worried he’s not getting any better either.

input: 1. A 6-year-old boy was brought to the neurology clinic with delayed motor milestones and difficulty walking independently. His parents noticed frequent falls and progressive muscle weakness, primarily affecting his proximal limbs. On examination, he exhibited hypotonia, calf hypertrophy, and mild joint contractures. Cognitive development appeared normal, but he showed signs of mild intellectual delay. Creatine kinase levels were elevated, and electromyography suggested a myopathic pattern. Brain MRI revealed subtle structural abnormalities consistent with cortical dysplasia. Muscle biopsy demonstrated reduced glycosylation of alpha-dystroglycan, confirming a diagnosis of Muscular Dystrophy-Dystroglycanopathy, Type a, 5. Genetic testing identified a mutation in the FKRP gene, supporting the clinical and pathological findings.Have you noticed if certain activities, settings, or times of day seem to make your symptoms worse or better, and how do you typically manage these fluctuations?
output: Um, he doesn’t really say much about times or places, but I think sometimes he just gets really tired and falls more, especially after playing or if he's been up longer. We try to help him rest or sit down, but I don’t know if that’s really making a difference.
